title: If a lien has been placed on my name can they take my 1993 truck
question: Creditor or in a civil case
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Judgment lien,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate
answers: The type of lien is hard to understand. Mr. Chen is correct about the judgment lien and the California exemption.

There are various types of liens. You don't indicate what type of lien. Is there a judgment against you?

Even assuming there is a personal property lien (which is obtained by filing a Notice of Judgment Lien with the Secretary of State), your 1993 truck would probably be exempt. In California, a motor vehicle up to $2,300 would be exempt (Cal. Civ. Proc. Code ยง 704.010).

A lien may have your name, but it is only secured on certain property. Specifically, an abstract of judgment, commonly referred to as "a lien," secures only the real property (real estate) in the county (or counties) where it was recorded with your name. It does not apply to your vehicle, which is personal property, unless there is a special type of lien filed with the DMV.

Again, the fact that it has your name on it does not mean that everything that you own now has a lien on it. However, if you have a judgment against you, if you give away valuable property to friends and family, you run the risk that you and them could be held liable for the tort of "fraudulent conveyance," which could subject both the debtor and gift recipient to be sued for such fraudulent conveyances. It may be rare in smaller debt cases, but it can happen if the debt collector's lawyer is very aggressive.
